comments.text:
In my opinion...anyone who believes in "Satan" is AS stupid as someone who 
believes in Satan's counterpart....Yahweh. They're BOTH mythical beings. 
100% imaginary. They live ONLY inside the minds of those who believe in 
them.
This woman doesn't worship Satan. She worships the CONCEPT of Satan in her 
own HEAD. Blaming Satan is just an excuse idiots use to throw away moral 
accountability. It's AS stupid as pretending all your immoral deeds are 
whitewashed because a guy died 2,000 years ago and became a zombie.

BOTH instances are cases of people trying to put their own moral 
responsibility on to a SCAPEGOAT. Satan and Jesus are BOTH used by 
unintelligent unethical people as excuses for their own behavior.

When will humanity grow the fuck up and stop with this archaic mythical 
nonsense? None of these imaginary beings we dream up exist. None of them. 
If you want to be a moral person...then BE a moral person. If you do 
something immoral...then YOU are immoral. And you don't get to wipe away 
your "sins" by appealing to the death of a fictional zombie.

Seriously....some beliefs are SO obviously false and SO incredibly absurd 
that it's absolutely shocking any sane person could find them even remotely 
plausible. It's high time we start calling such stupidity out for what it 
really is. Religion(which is nothing but a bunch of cults that got popular) 
has been nothing but a burden to our species. Religion has been THE single 
most dangerous, violent, repressive, anti-moral, anti-science, nihilistic, 
absurd idea the human species has ever invented.

Is there ANY sane ethical person left who still buys into this bullshit? I 
mean....seriously...how the hell does anyone take this stuff seriously? I'm 
sick and tired of religious people whining that "it's not us that's the 
problem...it's the beliefs of SOME religious people." No...you ARE the 
problem. You believe in the exact same book that the bigots and sociopaths 
believe in. Your belief that one book among all books is super-duper 
special...that gives credibility to the idiots who actually follow 
EVERYTHING their god says in such books. Just because sane religious people 
ignore 90% of what their god says doesn't make them justified. It just 
makes them hypocrites. Incredibly conceited arrogant hypocrites.

Put down the mythical ancient "holy" books and the various make-believe 
god(s) and demons that supposedly inspired these books. Instead, use your 
brain....make intelligent decisions, be moral for it's OWN sake, and last 
but not least....do your part to help liberate the minds of your fellow 
cult members...I mean, religious folk. Stop pandering to their insane 
beliefs. Stop pretending such people aren't bat-shit crazy. Start calling 
it out for what it actually is. Let's stop with all the politically correct 
walking on eggshells around the religious. They SHOULD be offended. They 
SHOULD be made to feel stupid. People need to be given a harsh dose of 
truth to snap them out of their various cults.

As a former born-again Christian myself, I'm grateful to the people that 
called out by bullshit beliefs. It hurt at the time....but later on I was 
grateful they didn't handle me with kid gloves. I'm glad certain people had 
the courage to tell me my beliefs were immoral and insane. It lead me to 
truly investigate the validity of my beliefs. Once I did that, it was 
inevitable that I'd let go of religion entirely. There's no other sane 
alternative. I'm SO much happier, ethically-minded, mentally healthy, 
empathetic, and educated now that I've let go of the greatest evil that 
ever infested humanity....religion.

Religion truly does poison EVERYTHING....especially your OWN mind. That's 
the saddest part of all...

+scarletrhubarb The concept of God is incoherent. Before you can start 
looking for evidence for something, you have to actually have an 
understanding of what it is you're looking for. If I asked you to provide 
evidence for a square circle, it raises the question as to how such an 
entity could ever even be conceived, let alone discovered. The concept of 
God falls in the same category, in that it is laden with many paradoxes. It 
is an inconceivable concept in the same way a square circle is an 
inconceivable concept since God is omnipotent, which brings up the question 
"Can God create something he cannot lift?". God is also usually defined as 
being omnibenevolent as well as omniscient, which begs the question "Does 
God know what it feels like to want to murder and rape children?" God is 
usually also characterized as a timeless and spaceless mind that also 
changes, which is inconceivable because everything that changes goes 
through time. With all these incongruities, it becomes impossible to even 
conceive of God's existence, so it is safe to say that God does not exist.

they instead make euphemisms out of terms like "agnostic" and "secular 
humanist," ignoring the fact that these words have their own specific 
definitions and are neither mutually exclusive nor mutually inclusive with 
"atheist." In fact, being an atheist doesn't say very much about a person;

comments.text:
Joseph Stalin was raised to be a Catholic Priest and I remain curious as to 
why his Christianity is shoved aside in all these arguments. Yes, there is 
no way to get around the fact that in his early career, Stalin made a vast 
effort to rid Russia of religion, but that had nothing to do with atheism. 
It was the only way he knew to seize power of the country.

For generations the entire populace of Russia had been taught that the head 
of state was supposed to be close to god. At the time in question, the head 
of the church in Russia was a tyrant. The Russians were already disposed to 
servility and all Stalin did was exploit these two facts, and place himself 
in the position of god. Once Stalin was firmly seated in office, he revived 
the Russian Orthodox Church in order to intensify patriotic support for the 
war effort. Stalin was part of a council convened to elected a new church 
Patriarch. Then the Russian theological schools were opened, and thousands 
of churches began to function. Even the Moscow Theological Academy Seminary 
was re-opened, after being closed since 1918.

So, while Stalin was no peach, he was not exactly what you would call a 
died-in-the-wool atheist. He was more a secular minded religious 
opportunist, which is a personal character trait. He did not use atheism to 
gain control, but religious principles that were modified to fit his own, 
sick and twisted method of revolution.

What about Pol Pot?

Truly a monster, having killed some twenty-five percent of the entire 
population of Cambodia. Pol Pot targeted not just different religions, but 
education, science and medicine in his quest for total domination. Now, 
let's take a head count of atheists who are against education, science and 
medicine. Thought so… Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge were composed of Buddhists and 
Pol Pot was a Theravada Buddhist. He studied at a Buddhist monastery and 
then at a Catholic school for 8 years. Cambodia's communism was influenced 
by Theravada Buddhism.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk said, "Pol Pot does not believe in God but he 
thinks that heaven, destiny, wants him to guide Cambodia in the way he 
thinks it the best for Cambodia, that is to say, the worst. Pol Pot is mad, 
you know, like Hitler."

So, while Pol Pot was definitely not a Christian, he was also definitely 
not an Atheist.

Let's get on with some Mass Murder, shall we?

Add up the deaths that were attributed to Hitler, Stalin and Pot. Then 
round up for good measure. You can safely say that the number is 
staggering. Probably upwards of fifteen million. However, consider the 
following conflicts where the only differences between the opposing 
factions were and are religion:

comments.text:
+o_O well, the bible is a compilation and therefore composed of several 
books from several authors. One of the greatest misunderstandings, from 
most believers and non-believers is the idea that all theses different 
authors - who lived in different times and wrote for different reasons - 
actually agree in a single message. Moreover, many believe that these books 
precisely define god as 'all-powerful' or 'all-knowing'. In reality, most 
of the books in the bible show very little concern in 'describing' god and 
much more ink is used in explaining how god - and other myths - are useful 
to the difficulties presented in the author's society and time.
As for 'god's power', considering only the early writings in the NT (Mark's 
gospel  and the authentic epistles of Paul), it seems as if the 'adversary' 
has control over the present age, but when god intervene that will change. 
Unfortunately, these ideas are not explicitly exposed and can only be 
inferred from the text, hence, lots of conflicting interpretations. Still, 
the most accepted view (among scholars) is that jesus believed that god had 
the ultimate power, but, for some unknown reason, gave away control over 
earth to the forces of evil until the 'return of the son of man' or some 
other apocalyptic moment, when god would assert his power.
Still, god's power would have always been absolute in the sense that the 
devil would have no power to stop god, when god decided to act.

top_comment.text:
Now before I say anything, I want to make it very clear that the Bible and 
ALL text written about the Christian god and the Christian satan are no 
different to me than the texts over the Greek gods. They are all mythology 
to me, and I see them as literature rather than fact.
That being said, I have read many different kinds of texts that paint 
Lucifer (Satan) in a very sympathetic light. For example, in John Milton's 
Paradise Lost, Lucifer is shown as defiant to God, but not in the way 
Christians typically tell it. Lucifer doesn't want to be subjugated. Anyone 
can relate to that feeling. No one wants to be told what to do all the time 
or be forced to be "under" someone else forever. He sees God as a tyrant 
and thinks all angels should rule as equal gods, which is why he leads a 
rebellion against his creator. 
To answer your question, Cenk, of why some worship Satan, I point to 
literature such as Milton's. Who do you think is more relatable in this 
story? God or Lucifer? The obvious answer is Lucifer. So when people decide 
to worship Satan rather than God, perhaps this is their mindset. That God 
is a tyrant and Lucifer was just trying to fight for equality.﻿
top_comment.author: Ceara McCord
